title: Hope and change, the Hebrew edition
content:
The campaign ad is hardly subtle : It offers a vision of hope and change , dismisses the scare tactics of an established candidate and insists that the old guard has “ already had their chance . ”
“ You have the strength to make a change . … This is the time for something new , ” the spot says .
The yes-we-can message may sound familiar to Americans who followed the 2008 presidential election — except that this time it ’ s delivered in Hebrew .
Nearly seven years after Barack Obama won the White House , his tech-savvy tactics and messaging strategy from 2008 continue to resonate in political campaigns across the globe . The latest case is Israel , where elections are set for March 17 . There , a grass-roots outfit known as “ Victory 2015 ” — V15 for short — is micro-targeting voters and pursuing a digital-first strategy in a country that ’ s used to seeing elections play out over the television airwaves . V15 has even tapped a former top Obama campaign aide for help .
“ People talk about the Obama campaign quite a lot , ” said V15 co-founder Nimrod Dweck , 33 . “ For me as an Israeli , I ’ m looking and saying , all right , it is possible to do an actual change . ”
V15 ’ s goal is to unseat hawkish Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu , whose recent decision to deliver a speech before Congress at the invitation of Republican House Speaker John Boehner — without White House buy-in — has prompted unusually high tensions between his government and the Obama administration . Some Democratic lawmakers are planning to skip the March 3 speech , and the fallout has raised concerns within the American Jewish community .
V15 is not allowed to coordinate with or endorse any campaign , but its chief beneficiary will likely be leading Netanyahu rival Isaac Herzog , who represents a more liberal alliance called the Zionist Union . Herzog has been hammering Netanyahu for stoking conflict with the speech , which is expected to , in effect , criticize the White House ’ s decision to pursue nuclear negotiations with Iran .
Netanyahu is favored to win reelection , and Obama himself is not especially popular in Israel . But V15 hopes it can cut into the prime minister ’ s margin by getting more center-left voters to turn out . The group ’ s strategy — and the parallels with the Obama campaign — go beyond simply calling for hope and change , though those terms are frequently invoked in V15 ’ s campaign literature .
In 2008 , for instance , the Obama campaign accused primary rival Hillary Clinton of playing on “ peoples ’ fears to scare up votes ” after a Clinton ad suggested she would be best-equipped to handle 3 a.m. crises . In a similar vein , V15 is dismissive of Netanyahu ’ s experience and near-singular focus on a muscular defense .
“ Your fear is good for them , ” intones a campaign ad that intersperses ominous images of the prime minister with more hopeful scenes of daily life , such as people dancing , painting and playing music . “ But it ’ s not you that ’ s afraid . It ’ s [ they ] who are afraid of you . ”
Both V15 and Herzog also have suggested that new leadership would improve Israel ’ s ties with the U.S. — just as Obama promised to improve America ’ s relations with the rest of the world following the presidency of George W. Bush . Herzog , while no dove , has also said that , if elected , he would resume peace talks with the Palestinians .
V15 has around 45 full-time staffers , and it says 10,000 people have volunteered to work on the campaign . It also has signed on Jeremy Bird , who served as national field director for Obama ’ s 2012 campaign . Bird ’ s firm , 270 Strategies , has been helping V15 target voters and improve its ground game .
Bird , who studied abroad in Israel during college , visited the country recently to help implement a canvassing program . His image was splashed across some Israeli newspapers .
The 36-year-old , whose firm has worked with Ready for Hillary , the organization pushing a Hillary Clinton 2016 presidential campaign , wasn ’ t made available for interview , but he said of V15 in a statement : “ We ’ re inspired by their passion — that ’ s why we were honored to be asked by V15 and its partners to share best practices in organizing so they can maximize their impact both online and on the ground . ”
American campaign tactics are increasingly being deployed in other countries , sometimes shepherded by other Obama alums , such as in the United Kingdom . In India ’ s 2014 election , political parties used some of the tech-driven outreach tactics that helped propel Obama to the White House .
U.S. consultants have been involved in Israeli campaigns since well before Obama rose to national prominence .
In 1999 , a cast of prominent Democratic operatives , some tied to then-U.S. President Bill Clinton , helped unseat Netanyahu . They included pollster Stan Greenberg and operatives James Carville and Bob Shrum . Netanyahu , who served from 1996 to 1999 and then again from 2009 through today , is the second-longest-serving prime minister in Israel ’ s 66-year history , following founding leader David Ben-Gurion .
A number of Americans beyond Bird are involved in this year ’ s Israeli election : Netanyahu ’ s party , Likud , has hired Kentucky GOP Sen. Rand Paul ’ s digital strategist , Vincent Harris . On the other side , longtime Clinton ally Paul Begala is advising Herzog . Democratic operative Mark Mellman is advising the centrist party Yesh Atid .
Observers say that while Israel is home to a vibrant start-up culture and plenty of digital know-how , the country of 8 million hasn ’ t yet seen data drive politics the way it increasingly does in U.S. elections . That ’ s what V15 is hoping to change .
Bird ’ s firm declined to say how many staffers it has assigned to the V15 project . V15 has about 20 people working on a data team , which is focused on identifying targets for get-out-the-vote efforts . It took statistics from previous elections , combined that with demographic data and incorporated that into software that dictates where to focus its outreach .
“ We managed to actually do a real mapping of Israel : Where we should operate , how much manpower is needed , how much door-to-door [ we should do ] , ” Dweck said . “ 270 helped us introduce metrics into how many doors were opened and conversations engaged . ”
But for all of V15 ’ s enthusiasm , the bulk of the campaigning is still driven by the major parties , rather than by outside groups . In this instance , that means efforts by Likud vs. the more liberal Zionist Union , an alliance of center-left parties .
“ Israel is a very small country , the size of New Jersey , and any serious outreach efforts can have some marginal effect , ” said Natan Sachs , an expert on Israeli politics at the Brookings Institution . “ But generally , it ’ s small . Israelis are very engaged in politics , the Israeli parties are very adept at reaching their audiences . ”
V15 was connected to 270 Strategies through the pro-peace group OneVoice , with which 270 Strategies has done some work and which is now an official V15 partner in Israel .
OneVoice , which also has an American branch , was founded by Daniel Lubetzky , who heads Kind healthy snacks , known for its granola bars . Lubetzky is a major contributor to V15 , as is S. Daniel Abraham , a prominent American Jewish billionaire who served as the chairman of Slim-Fast .
V15 , which accepts foreign donations , is not supposed to coordinate with or endorse any campaign . Still , Netanyahu ’ s Likud allies have accused it of coordinating with Herzog ’ s camp and otherwise violating campaign laws ; V15 denies wrongdoing ( and Israel ’ s attorney general tossed out a Likud effort to disqualify the group , though it said V15 could face scrutiny over donors following the election ) .
Sen. Ted Cruz of Texas and Rep. Lee Zeldin of New York , both Republicans , have questioned whether a State Department-approved grant to OneVoice constituted an Obama-led “ political campaign against ” Netanyahu . State Department spokeswoman Jen Psaki said in a briefing late last month that the grant expired before elections were even called , and before V15 ’ s existence .
Dweck said he ’ s hopeful that data-driven , American-style tactics help make the March 17 election a competitive one .
“ We ’ ve never had the firsthand experience of how you guys actually operate and work , ” he said . “ We have a lot to learn from American politics . ”
content_original:
The campaign ad is hardly subtle: It offers a vision of hope and change, dismisses the scare tactics of an established candidate and insists that the old guard has “already had their chance.”

“You have the strength to make a change. … This is the time for something new,” the spot says.

Story Continued Below

The yes-we-can message may sound familiar to Americans who followed the 2008 presidential election — except that this time it’s delivered in Hebrew.

Nearly seven years after Barack Obama won the White House, his tech-savvy tactics and messaging strategy from 2008 continue to resonate in political campaigns across the globe. The latest case is Israel, where elections are set for March 17. There, a grass-roots outfit known as “Victory 2015” — V15 for short — is micro-targeting voters and pursuing a digital-first strategy in a country that’s used to seeing elections play out over the television airwaves. V15 has even tapped a former top Obama campaign aide for help.

“People talk about the Obama campaign quite a lot,” said V15 co-founder Nimrod Dweck, 33. “For me as an Israeli, I’m looking and saying, all right, it is possible to do an actual change.”

V15’s goal is to unseat hawkish Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, whose recent decision to deliver a speech before Congress at the invitation of Republican House Speaker John Boehner — without White House buy-in — has prompted unusually high tensions between his government and the Obama administration. Some Democratic lawmakers are planning to skip the March 3 speech, and the fallout has raised concerns within the American Jewish community.

V15 is not allowed to coordinate with or endorse any campaign, but its chief beneficiary will likely be leading Netanyahu rival Isaac Herzog, who represents a more liberal alliance called the Zionist Union. Herzog has been hammering Netanyahu for stoking conflict with the speech, which is expected to, in effect, criticize the White House’s decision to pursue nuclear negotiations with Iran.

Netanyahu is favored to win reelection, and Obama himself is not especially popular in Israel. But V15 hopes it can cut into the prime minister’s margin by getting more center-left voters to turn out. The group’s strategy — and the parallels with the Obama campaign — go beyond simply calling for hope and change, though those terms are frequently invoked in V15’s campaign literature.

In 2008, for instance, the Obama campaign accused primary rival Hillary Clinton of playing on “peoples’ fears to scare up votes” after a Clinton ad suggested she would be best-equipped to handle 3 a.m. crises. In a similar vein, V15 is dismissive of Netanyahu’s experience and near-singular focus on a muscular defense.

“Your fear is good for them,” intones a campaign ad that intersperses ominous images of the prime minister with more hopeful scenes of daily life, such as people dancing, painting and playing music. “But it’s not you that’s afraid. It’s [they] who are afraid of you.”

Both V15 and Herzog also have suggested that new leadership would improve Israel’s ties with the U.S. — just as Obama promised to improve America’s relations with the rest of the world following the presidency of George W. Bush. Herzog, while no dove, has also said that, if elected, he would resume peace talks with the Palestinians.

V15 has around 45 full-time staffers, and it says 10,000 people have volunteered to work on the campaign. It also has signed on Jeremy Bird, who served as national field director for Obama’s 2012 campaign. Bird’s firm, 270 Strategies, has been helping V15 target voters and improve its ground game.

Bird, who studied abroad in Israel during college, visited the country recently to help implement a canvassing program. His image was splashed across some Israeli newspapers.

The 36-year-old, whose firm has worked with Ready for Hillary, the organization pushing a Hillary Clinton 2016 presidential campaign, wasn’t made available for interview, but he said of V15 in a statement: “We’re inspired by their passion — that’s why we were honored to be asked by V15 and its partners to share best practices in organizing so they can maximize their impact both online and on the ground.”

American campaign tactics are increasingly being deployed in other countries, sometimes shepherded by other Obama alums, such as in the United Kingdom. In India’s 2014 election, political parties used some of the tech-driven outreach tactics that helped propel Obama to the White House.

U.S. consultants have been involved in Israeli campaigns since well before Obama rose to national prominence.

In 1999, a cast of prominent Democratic operatives, some tied to then-U.S. President Bill Clinton, helped unseat Netanyahu. They included pollster Stan Greenberg and operatives James Carville and Bob Shrum. Netanyahu, who served from 1996 to 1999 and then again from 2009 through today, is the second-longest-serving prime minister in Israel’s 66-year history, following founding leader David Ben-Gurion.

A number of Americans beyond Bird are involved in this year’s Israeli election: Netanyahu’s party, Likud, has hired Kentucky GOP Sen. Rand Paul’s digital strategist, Vincent Harris. On the other side, longtime Clinton ally Paul Begala is advising Herzog. Democratic operative Mark Mellman is advising the centrist party Yesh Atid.

Observers say that while Israel is home to a vibrant start-up culture and plenty of digital know-how, the country of 8 million hasn’t yet seen data drive politics the way it increasingly does in U.S. elections. That’s what V15 is hoping to change.

Bird’s firm declined to say how many staffers it has assigned to the V15 project. V15 has about 20 people working on a data team, which is focused on identifying targets for get-out-the-vote efforts. It took statistics from previous elections, combined that with demographic data and incorporated that into software that dictates where to focus its outreach.

“We managed to actually do a real mapping of Israel: Where we should operate, how much manpower is needed, how much door-to-door [we should do],” Dweck said. “270 helped us introduce metrics into how many doors were opened and conversations engaged.”

But for all of V15’s enthusiasm, the bulk of the campaigning is still driven by the major parties, rather than by outside groups. In this instance, that means efforts by Likud vs. the more liberal Zionist Union, an alliance of center-left parties.

“Israel is a very small country, the size of New Jersey, and any serious outreach efforts can have some marginal effect,” said Natan Sachs, an expert on Israeli politics at the Brookings Institution. “But generally, it’s small. Israelis are very engaged in politics, the Israeli parties are very adept at reaching their audiences.”

V15 was connected to 270 Strategies through the pro-peace group OneVoice, with which 270 Strategies has done some work and which is now an official V15 partner in Israel.

OneVoice, which also has an American branch, was founded by Daniel Lubetzky, who heads Kind healthy snacks, known for its granola bars. Lubetzky is a major contributor to V15, as is S. Daniel Abraham, a prominent American Jewish billionaire who served as the chairman of Slim-Fast.

V15, which accepts foreign donations, is not supposed to coordinate with or endorse any campaign. Still, Netanyahu’s Likud allies have accused it of coordinating with Herzog’s camp and otherwise violating campaign laws; V15 denies wrongdoing (and Israel’s attorney general tossed out a Likud effort to disqualify the group, though it said V15 could face scrutiny over donors following the election).

Sen. Ted Cruz of Texas and Rep. Lee Zeldin of New York, both Republicans, have questioned whether a State Department-approved grant to OneVoice constituted an Obama-led “political campaign against” Netanyahu. State Department spokeswoman Jen Psaki said in a briefing late last month that the grant expired before elections were even called, and before V15’s existence.

Dweck said he’s hopeful that data-driven, American-style tactics help make the March 17 election a competitive one.

“We’ve never had the firsthand experience of how you guys actually operate and work,” he said. “We have a lot to learn from American politics.”

Hadas Gold contributed to this report.
